Although Andorra's borders remain open, foreign visitors must meet travel requirements set by neighboring France and Spain to reach the country. Tourists over 6 years of age staying for 3 or more nights in the country must have a vaccination, recovery or test certificate which they must provide at their tourist accommodation or show to the public authorities. French, Spanish and Portuguese nationals are exempt from having/showing these certificates. All citizens coming from all countries considered to be a "green zone" will also be exempt from having and/or exhibiting a certificate. As well as citizens from countries with a test ratio equal to or over 5,000 tests per week per 100,000 inhabitants and a positivity rate of less than 5%. Anyone traveling to Andorra from Brazil, South Africa or India must be quarantined for a period of 14 calendar days and must present a negative result of a diagnostic test taken 72 hours before arriving in Andorra.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210823093215/https://visitandorra.com/en/covid-19-in-andorra/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210823093702/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/512971/andorra-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-restrictions-as-of-aug-13-update-12

At the end of May 2021, the authorities announced a new package of extraordinary measures, in force starting from July 1st, upon expiration of the previous package, and in place until December 31st, 2021 (or 90 days after the declaration of the end of the health crisis, if earlier). The new package extends existing measures, particularly those related to short-time work schemes (STW) and benefits to self-employed, but made conditions for applicability more restrictive, only to cases in which businesses activity continues to be severely affected by the pandemic. The government also approved a new program of rent/mortgage payment support for travel agencies and nightclubs, in place only during July.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210802055800/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The government has  has relaxed the conditions to access available Covid-19 relief funds, incorporating additional purposes for requesting the guaranteed loans, which now include the payment of rent and utility bills.     The government has also extended the program of aid for rent and mortgage payments of authorized establishments such as pubs, nightclubs, ballrooms or similar and travel agencies, from July during the month of August.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210802055800/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210823172239/https://www.govern.ad/presidencia-economia-i-empresa/item/13127-el-govern-prorroga-durant-el-mes-d-agost-el-programa-d-ajuts-al-lloguer-i-a-les-hipoteques-de-pubs-discoteques-sales-de-balls-i-agencies-de-viatge

As of July 25, the government announced an additional screening protocol for visitors and residents in social and health centers for the elderly. The protocol maintains the current regime of visits and outings abroad, but establishes various criteria for daily outings, overnight stays outside the center and visits from abroad.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210802055119/https://www.govern.ad/salut/item/13128-el-certificat-digital-covid-ja-esta-disponible-a-l-aplicacio-andorrasalut

For reference: "One month before the start of the new school year 2021/22, Minister of Education Heinz FaÃmann presented a four-point plan to ensure school operations without extensive school closings and shift work, despite the delta variant and the increasing number of corona infections"    "Corona tests three times a week are fixed in the first two weeks after school starts as part of the head of department's security pact. Vaccinated people are "privileged": for them there are no longer any restrictions on face-to-face operation after the first two weeks."    "The quality of the corona tests will be improved. Instead of the antigen tests three times a week, there will be a PCR flush test ("everything flushes") once a week throughout Austria in the new school year. These flush tests are carried out jointly in the classes on Monday, the results should be available by Tuesday. Swiss Post will be the partner for the logistics for collecting the tests."    Source: https://archive.vn/T0S1v [Wiener Zeitung]

Nationwide guidelines  â¢ From Monday, May 17, 2021, all Austrian schools will be continuously in attendance in compliance with the 3-G rule.   â¢ At the moment, teaching and examination operations at universities, as well as research and administration, should be carried out digitally if possible.    NB Where courses required it, some universities were holding in-person classes.     Special regulations for Carinthia  The following additional, stricter measures apply to the federal state of Carinthia:  â¢ The 3-G rule applies when entering child education and care facilities, as well as day-care centers and when staying in closed rooms in these facilities. If this is not provided, an MNS must be worn.  â¢ The provider of a facility has to implement the requirements of the COVID-19 guidelines for child education and care facilities.  â¢ Activities should be relocated to the open where this appears educationally sensible and organizationally possible. At events, the requirements of the 2nd COVID-19 Opening Ordinance must be observed.  â¢ The 3-G certificate is a prerequisite for caring for children in after-school care centers. If this cannot be achieved, the child has to wear an MNS.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210813214438/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210812120016/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html

Nationwide guidelines  â¢ From Monday, May 17, 2021, all Austrian schools will be continuously in attendance in compliance with the 3-G rule.   â¢ At the moment, teaching and examination operations at universities, as well as research and administration, should be carried out digitally if possible.    NB Where necessary for courses - some universities holding in-person classes.     *Special regulations for Carinthia*  The following additional, stricter measures apply to the federal state of Carinthia:     â¢  The 3-G rule applies when entering child education and care facilities, as well as day-care centers and when staying in closed rooms in these facilities. If this is not provided, an MNS must be worn.   â¢  The provider of a facility has to implement the requirements of the COVID-19 guidelines for child education and care facilities.   â¢  Activities should be relocated to the open where this appears educationally sensible and organizationally possible. At events, the requirements of the 2nd COVID-19 Opening Ordinance must be observed.   â¢  The 3-G certificate is a prerequisite for caring for children in after-school care. If this cannot be achieved, the child has to wear an MNS.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/JAJ5H [Current measures nationwide]  https://archive.vn/7Y3cG [An overview of current measures in Carinthia]

The safety phase at the beginning of school is extended to three weeks (originally two weeks) with students being tested three times a week. What happens after that depends on the risk situation. as informed by the Corona Commission's weekly risk-adjusted 7-day incidence for each district and each federal state.    "...federal government wants to take temporally and regionally limited measures in the new school year. This is intended to maintain the presence of the schools, and comprehensive school closings are to be avoided."    Source: https://archive.vn/mZYFR [Wiener Zeitung reporting on Ministry of Education press conference on schools opening]

A number of sectors are only open to those who are able to show 3G proof, so these workplaces are in effect restricted to the unvaccinated..      At work  â¢ Workplaces may only be entered by teachers who are in direct contact with students, owners, operators and employees with direct customer contact, persons who are active in dealing with parties in administrative authorities and administrative courts, if they are in contact with students, with customers and with parties wear a mask in closed rooms unless the risk of infection is minimized by other suitable protective measures.    â¢ The obligation to wear a mask does not apply if the persons present a 3-G certificate.    â¢ The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.    â¢ By agreement between employers and employees, stricter rules for wearing a mask, an FFP2 mask without an exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard can be made in addition to the arrangements made for wearing a mask.    The 3-G rule applies in the following areas:  â¢ Gastronomy  â¢ Body-hugging services  â¢ Hotel and lodging  â¢ Leisure facilities ( e.g.  dance schools, zoos)  â¢ Cultural establishments (with the exception of museums, libraries, libraries and archives)  â¢ Non-public sports facilities  â¢ Meetings (from one participant: more than 100 people)  â¢ Trade and consumer fairs, congresses  â¢ Coaches and excursion boats    In addition, the 3G rule continues to apply in the following areas and for the following people:  â¢ In the provision of mobile care and support services  â¢ For visitors and employees of retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled  â¢ For residents for new admission in old people's and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled  â¢ For visitors and employees of hospitals or health resorts  â¢ For employees from other locations where health services are provided.    Night gastronomy  â¢ From July 22nd, access to the night catering is only possible for vaccinated people and people with a current negative PCR test result (maximum 72 hours from sampling).    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210813214438/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210812120016/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html

A number of sectors are only open to those who are able to show 3G proof. These workplaces are in effect restricted to the unvaccinated.    The 3-G rule applies in the following areas:  â¢ Gastronomy  â¢ Body-hugging services  â¢ Hotel and lodging  â¢ Leisure facilities ( e.g.  dance schools, zoos)  â¢ Cultural establishments (with the exception of museums, libraries, libraries and archives)  â¢ Non-public sports facilities  â¢ Meetings (from one participant: more than 100 people)  â¢ Trade and consumer fairs, congresses  â¢ Coaches and excursion boats    In addition, the 3G rule continues to apply in the following areas and for the following people:  â¢ In the provision of mobile care and support services  â¢ For visitors and employees of retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled  â¢ For residents for new admission in old people's and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled  â¢ For visitors and employees of hospitals or health resorts  â¢ For employees from other locations where health services are provided.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/R0DuP [Coronavirus - Current Measures]  https://web.archive.org/web/20210813214438/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/ [Nationwide measures]

Events fall under the guidelines for 'meetings'.  So while there are no limits in theory, there in fact requirements for larger events with over 100 people, and 500 or more requires approval in advance.     The following rules apply to meetings:    â¢ Meetings of 100 people or more are notifiable (district administrative authority)  â¢ Meetings of 500 people or more must be approved  â¢ In principle, there are no maximum limits and capacity restrictions    "From 100 people, the participants must present a 3-G certificate, which must be checked by the responsible person. He must also develop and implement a prevention concept and appoint a COVID-19 officer."    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210813214438/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210812120016/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html

Events sit in the guidelines for 'meetings'.  So while there are no limits in theory, there in fact requirements for larger events with over 100 people, and 500 or more requires approval in advance.     Meetings  The following rules apply to meetings:    â¢ Meetings of 100 people or more are notifiable (district administrative authority)  â¢ Meetings of 500 people or more must be approved  â¢ In principle, there are no maximum limits and capacity restrictions    For more than 100 people, the participants must present a 3-G certificate, which must be checked by the responsible person. He must also develop and implement a prevention concept and appoint a COVID-19 officer.    Source: https://archive.vn/R0DuP#selection-2009.0-2067.67

Measures for individual districts - Lienz (Tyrol)  "From August 11, 2021 (until September 1, 2021), the following applies to the entire Lienz district: Meetings of more than 100 people are not permitted. In any case, a mask (FFP2) must be worn at permissible gatherings, a 3G verification must be checked and a registration must be carried out. An FFP2 mask must also be worn in closed rooms in retail, in customer areas, when collecting food, in cultural institutions, at workplaces, in old people's and nursing homes and hospitals, in public closed rooms and on public transport."    Elsewhere in Austria  "Meetings of 100 people or more are notifiable. The participants have to show a 3G certificate, which has to be checked by those responsible. The latter must also develop and implement a prevention concept and appoint a COVID-19 officer."    Sources:  https://archive.vn/Fulk4 [Tyrol specific measures]  https://archive.vn/8fEMv {Ordinance]  https://archive.vn/ZBDCB [Nationwide measures]

Measures for individual districts - Lienz (Tyrol)  "From August 11, 2021 (until September 1, 2021), the following applies to the entire Lienz district: Meetings of more than 100 people are not permitted. In any case, a mask (FFP2) must be worn at permissible gatherings, a 3G verification must be checked and a registration must be carried out. An FFP2 mask must also be worn in closed rooms in retail, in customer areas, when collecting food, in cultural institutions, at workplaces, in old people's and nursing homes and hospitals, in public closed rooms and on public transport." Mouth and nose protection & mask compulsory  In all places where the 3-G rule applies, there is no mask requirement. This also applies to employees in those areas in which a 3-G certificate is intended.    There are exceptions to the omission of the mask requirement for retirement and nursing homes as well as health facilities. The following groups of people are required to wear mouth and nose protection:    â¢ Visitors and employees of retirement and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled  â¢ Visitors and employees of hospitals or health resorts  â¢ Employees, patients, visitors and accompanying persons from other locations where health services are provided.  The respective institution can also provide more stringent regulations.    In addition, it is mandatory to wear mouth and nose protection in closed rooms in the following areas:    â¢ public transport and its stations  â¢ Taxis  â¢ Cable cars and cog railways  â¢ in customer areas  â¢ at administrative authorities and administrative courts in the context of party relations  â¢ in customer areas of business premises ( e.g.  supermarket, retail, etc.) when in contact with customers (from July 22nd at places of daily use - e.g. supermarket, pharmacy, bank, etc. )    In Vienna  From July 22nd, the mask requirement will continue to apply in Vienna in museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives, theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas as well as institutions for religious practice.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210813214438/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210812120016/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701195313/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/regionale-zusaetzliche-massnahmen/wien/

An MNS must be worn in everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and in grocery stores. A mask in the sense of this ordinance is a close-fitting mechanical protective device (MNS) that covers the mouth and nose area.     There is no minimum distance of one meter from other people. In all places where the 3-G rule applies, there is no mask requirement. This also applies to employees in those areas in which a 3-G certificate is intended.    Hospitals and health resorts  â¢ Employees must wear an MNS in closed rooms.    â¢ The operator may only let in visitors and accompanying persons if they wear a mask throughout the visit or stay, provided that there is no other suitable protective device for spatial separation between residents and visitors or accompanying persons that provides the same level of protection guaranteed.    In VIenna  From July 22nd, the mask requirement will continue to apply in Vienna in museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives, theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas as well as institutions for religious practice.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/ZBDCB#selection-2663.0-2663.304 [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/33fKd [Vienna]

"An mRNA vaccine is recommended for this additional dose in all cases," writes the vaccination board."    Source: https://archive.vn/wFbrz

Health and social sector guidelines    **Retirement and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled**    The following applies to visitors:    The operator may only let in visitors and accompanying persons if they can provide evidence of a low epidemiological risk (3-G rule). The visitor or the accompanying person must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.  The operator may only let in visitors and accompanying persons if they wear a mask throughout the visit or stay, provided that there is no other suitable protective device for spatial separation between residents and visitors or accompanying persons that provides the same level of protection guaranteed.    The following applies to employees:   Employees need proof of a low epidemiological risk. If a test certificate is presented, it must be renewed every seven days. If the 3-G proof provided has exceeded its validity, an FFP2 mask must be worn.  Employees must wear an FFP2 mask in closed rooms.    The following applies to operators:  Operators of retirement and nursing homes as well as residential facilities for the disabled have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.     **Mobile care and support services**  Providers of mobile care and support services require evidence of a low epidemiological risk. If a test certificate is presented, it must be renewed every seven days. If the 3-G proof provided has exceeded its validity, an FFP2 mask must be worn.  In addition, an MNS must be worn in closed rooms.    **Hospitals and health resorts**  The following applies to visitors:    The operator may only let in visitors and accompanying persons if they can provide evidence of a low epidemiological risk (3-G rule). The visitor or the accompanying person must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.  The operator may only let in visitors and accompanying persons if they wear a mask throughout the visit or stay, provided that there is no other suitable protective device for spatial separation between the resident and the visitor or accompanying person that guarantees the same level of protection.    The following applies to employees:   Employees need proof of a low epidemiological risk. If a test certificate is presented, it must be renewed every seven days. If the 3-G proof provided has exceeded its validity, an FFP2 mask must be worn.  Employees must wear an MNS in closed rooms.    The following applies to operators:  Operators of hospitals and health resorts have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.     Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210813214438/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210701195313/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/regionale-zusaetzliche-massnahmen/wien/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210812120016/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html

Quote: "The government of Azerbaijan plans to open international air travel with 20 additional countries as part of the nation's gradual easing of its COVID-19-related restrictions. Effective Aug. 5, citizens and legal residents of Austria, Belgium, Canada, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Serbia, Singapore, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, and Switzerland will be allowed to travel to Azerbaijan by air without the previously required special permission provided they meet the following conditions:    All passengers over the age of 18 years must possess official documentation (i.e. COVID Passport) issued by the relevant country demonstrating that they have either been fully vaccinated against or have recovered from COVID-19, in addition to a negative result from a PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to their flight.    All passengers between the ages of 1-18 years must possess a negative result from a PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to their flight.    There are no such document requirements for infants aged less than one year.    Citizens and legal residents of Bahrain, Hungary, Israel, Qatar, Russia, Turkey, the UAE, the UK, and the US have been permitted to travel to Azerbaijan under the same conditions since July 22. Authorities plan to perform periodic assessments and ease entry restrictions for travelers from other locations. Returning Azerbaijani nationals require only a negative result from a PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to their flight to enter the country. For further details on requirements for entering Azerbaijan, click here.    Land and maritime borders remain closed. The only option for entry and exit is via air on a limited number of commercial and charter flights operating to and from selected destinations. "  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210817145739/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/509101/azerbaijan-government-to-allow-foreign-travel-from-20-additional-countries-effective-aug-5-update-36

FBiH:  Catering establishments may offer food and drinks outdoors (summer garden, terrace) as well as indoors, whereby the seating tables must be visibly marked. A maximum of four people are allowed per table. In supermarkets and drugstores, only one person is allowed per 10 m2 of space. Regardless of the size of the area, there must never be more than 400 people in shopping malls. All existing cash registers must be constantly occupied. Companies are obliged to engage surveillance personnel to supervise the number of people within the facility, as well as when entering and leaving the facility.    RS:All shops and establishments must take additional hygiene measures and disinfect them continuously.  All companies, entrepreneurs and natural persons who provide services to citizens in direct contact must provide the masks for citizens who do not have them, as well as monitor compliance with the measures with security guards.  Catering establishments and gambling operators can be kept open from 6.00 a.m. to 24.00 p.m.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210817062100/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

FBiH:  Public gatherings of more than 100 people outdoors and more than 50 people indoors are prohibited. A distance of 2 m must be observed. This does not apply to parliamentary sittings. Exceptionally, a maximum of 100 people may be present in theatres and cinemas, congresses, conferences and other educational events. It is also possible to organize larger gatherings (up to a maximum of 150 people indoors and a maximum of up to 300 people outdoors) under specially defined conditions, i.e. all participants need either an antigen or PCR test, not older than 48 hours, or a certificate of recovery, not older than six months, or a certificate of a fully performed vaccination. All epidemiological measures must be complied with. Organizers are obliged to register all planned events with the cantonal ministries of health.    RS:  All public gatherings of more than 120 people are prohibited.  Between 6.00 and 3.00 a.m., the public is again allowed to participate in competitive activities of sports clubs and athletes with compliance with epidemiological measures.  Between 6.00 and 3.00 a.m. the organization of cultural events and open air festivals is permitted with compliance with epidemiological measures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210817062100/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

Since 11.6.2021, entry for foreign citizens is possible under the following conditions:     negative PCR test or rapid antigen test for SARS-CoV-2 not older than 48 hours (for those arriving from Europe) or not older than 72 hours (for those arriving outside Europe), calculated from the time of smear collection to arrival at the border crossing.    Vaccination certificate for people who received a second dose of the COVID-19 vaccine more than 14 days ago. Exception: single-dose vaccine (Janssen/Johnson & Johnson), a certificate of receipt of the single dose more than 14 days before the date of crossing the state border.   Medical confirmation that the traveler has recovered from COVID-19. This confirmation is valid at the earliest on the 14th day and at the latest until the 180th day from the date of the positive test.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210817062100/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

FBiH:  Masks are mandatory with a physical distance of 2 m in closed public spaces. Children under the age of 6, disabled persons, athletes and persons who carry out sporting leisure activities in sports halls are exempt from compulsory masks. Outdoors, masks are only mandatory if the distance cannot be maintained (marketplaces, stops and similar).    RS:  Masks are mandatory in closed rooms, as well as a personal distance of 2 m. Children under the age of 7, the disabled and persons who carry out sporting leisure activities in sports halls are exempt from compulsory masks. If the distance cannot be maintained, masks are also recommended outdoors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210817062100/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

No policy change.   There are several restrictions for travelers to Switzerland. Those tourists that come from areas without variants of concern that have not been vaccinated are required to present a negative test but are not subject to quarantine. Those unvaccinated who come from higher-risk areas must present a negative test and quarantine once they arrive.     Those unvaccinated that come from high-risk areas without a valid visa and without meeting any of the travel requirements imposed by the Swiss government cannot enter the country. Some of these requirements are having a Swiss resident permit, A Schengen country resident permit, or a cross-border permit.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210724100159/https://www.sem.admin.ch/sem/en/home/sem/aktuell/faq-einreiseverweigerung.html

No evidence of policy change. There are several restrictions for travelers to Switzerland. Those tourists that come from areas without variants of concern that have not been vaccinated are required to present a negative test but are not subject to quarantine. Those unvaccinated who come from higher-risk areas must present a negative test and quarantine once they arrive. It is important to note, however, that there are no countries that are considered areas of concern by the Swiss authorities.     Those unvaccinated that come from high-risk areas without a valid visa and without meeting any of the travel requirements imposed by the Swiss government cannot enter the country. Some of these requirements are having a Swiss resident permit, A Schengen country resident permit, or a cross-border permit.     Those that are either unvaccinated or unable to show evidence of recovery from Covid will have to present proof of a negative PCR test (not older than 72 hours) or rapid antigen test (not older than 48 hours).     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210818033658/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210820025254/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/liste.html

Tests are generally available in Switzerland, and the government subsidizes their costs (it doesn't fund a test only if a citizen needs it to travel). The SwissCovid app notifies citizens when they should get a test.   "Get tested immediately if you have coronavirus symptoms. You should also get tested if you only have very mild or isolated symptoms. Also get tested if you suspect you have been infected (e.g. following contact with an infected person or after receiving a notification from the SwissCovid app)."     PCR, antigen, and antigen self-tests are available in Switzerland.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210806101753/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/testen.html

Also get tested if you suspect you have been infected (e.g. following contact with an infected person or after receiving a notification from the SwissCovid app)." This is what can be found on governmental sources:  On 25 August 2021 the Swiss Federal Council decided to adjust the national testing strategy.  The following still applies:    -Anyone with symptoms or close contact with a confirmed case should be tested as a matter of urgency. In this case, the federal government will cover the costs of the test.  The federal government continues to recommend and fund repeat tests in educational, training and healthcare institutions, as well as in companies.  In healthcare institutions: to protect people at high risk, repeat tests for staff, patients and residents will be introduced or continued.  In schools, universities and childcare facilities: to help normalise teaching, school life and care, and to nip outbreaks of infection in the bud, repeat tests will be continued.  Repeat tests in companies continue to be encouraged.  From 1 October 2021 the following applies:    The federal government will no longer pay for rapid antigen tests for asymptomatic people (e.g. for a test certificate). There are exceptions for:  - Children and young people under age 16  - People who cannot be vaccinated on medical grounds (medical certificate required)  - People visiting healthcare institutions (no Covid test certificate issued)  Tests for symptomatic people and those who have had close contact with an infected person, and confirmatory PCR tests, will basically no longer lead to a Covid certificate  Self-tests will basically no longer be covered by the federal government    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210829144923/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/testen.html

No policy change. Tests are generally available in Switzerland, and the government subsidizes their costs (it doesn't fund a test only if a citizen needs it to travel). The SwissCovid app notifies citizens when they should get a test.   "Get tested immediately if you have coronavirus symptoms. You should also get tested if you only have very mild or isolated symptoms. Also get tested if you suspect you have been infected (e.g. following contact with an infected person or after receiving a notification from the SwissCovid app)."     PCR, antigen, and antigen self-tests are available in Switzerland.     In addition, a new campaign has been launched to test Swiss citizens coming from their holidays since "summer holidays mean more contact between people". This is what can be found on official sources: "Anyone who has neither been vaccinated nor has recovered from COVID should have a test when they get back from their holidays â regardless of whether they were in Switzerland or abroad. This is the goal of a campaign under the banner of âGet tested after holidays â even with no symptoms.â This is because people returning from holidays may be carrying and spreading the virus, even if they donât have symptoms".    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210813175450/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/das-bag/aktuell/news/news-02-08-2021.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210813175502/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/testen.html

No policy change. The Swiss government continues to use the SwissCovid app to identify people who have had close contact with infected individuals: "The SwissCovid app supports this process, establishing whether close contact has taken place and giving rapid notification if there is a potential risk of infection".  More information about how this app works can be found in the following link:    http://web.archive.org/web/20210724101148/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/swisscovid-app-und-contact-tracing.html

There's no policy change in respect to the vaccination process. In addition to the initially prioritized groups 1, and 2,  most cantons are now vaccinating the wider population (target groups 3, 4, 5, and 6). Workplaces are open, however, all employees, including self-employed persons, should hold either a negative Covid19 laboratory or antigen rapid test performed within 72 hours, or a certificate of vaccination against Covid-19 for at least one dose and provided that three weeks have elapsed after the date of vaccination or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 and provided that a period of six months has not elapsed since the date of the initial positive diagnosis    See Decree 32    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210802161731/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/30072021_Decree32_EN.pdf

Gatherings at private residences will be limited to 20 people per residence, including minor children and hosts. This however, does not apply to certain events such as weddings and christenings which require that participants aged 12 and above have a negative laboratory test or rapid antigen test result for COVID-19 with the sampling having been taken within 72 hours, or a vaccination certificate for COVID-19 with at least one dose administered and provided that three weeks have elapsed since the vaccination date, or a document proving the release of persons who have been infected with COVID-19 and provided that no more than six months have elapsed since the sampling date of their initial diagnosis    See Decree 31    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210730224211/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/19072021_Decree%20No%2031%20EN.pdf

Cyprus follows a colour-coded system which grades countries into GREEN, ORANGE, RED & GREY. Persons travelling from countries labelled GREEN require a Cyprus Flight Pass completion 48h prior to departure, those coming from countries labelled ORANGE require the flight pass in addition to a PCR test 72 hours prior to departure. Those in the countries labelled RED require a flight pass, a PCR test 72 hours prior to departure, and a PCR test on arrival in Cyprus. People coming from countries labelled GREY require a flight pass, a PCR test 72 hours prior to departure, a PCR test on arrival in Cyprus and are also required mandatorily to self-isolate upon arrival.    Archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210730232930/https://www.visitcyprus.com/files/COVID-19_Destination_Protocol_Cyprus_-1st_July_21_FINAL.pdf
No change in policy     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210802162638/https://www.visitcyprus.com/files/COVID-19_Destination_Protocol_Cyprus_-1st_July_21_FINAL.pdf

New update on 9th Aug  https://archive.is/1LI0E  passengers coming from the Green Category countries are not required to hold a COVID-19 test certificate or self-isolate.  passengers coming from Orange Category countries shall be required to undergo a PCR laboratory test within 72 hours prior to departure and to possess a certificate showing a negative PCR result.  passengers coming from Red Category countries shall be required to: a) undergo a PCR laboratory test within 72 hours prior to departure proving a negative PCR result and b) undergo a laboratory test upon their arrival in the Republic of Cyprus.  Passengers arriving in the Republic of Cyprus from the Grey Category countries (Special Permission) shall remain in mandatory self-isolation or mandatory quarantine for a period of fourteen (14) days or alternatively, in mandatory self-isolation or mandatory quarantine for a period of seven (7) days provided that they undergo another Covid19 test (at their own expense) on the 7th day and the result comes back negative.

Travellers with proof of two COVID-19 vaccinations are not required to take a PCR test before departure or on arrival. If you have received two vaccinations you will still need to obtain a Cyprus flight pass. You should check the Cyprus Flight Pass website for information on which vaccinations are acceptable, and the length of time which should have elapsed between your final dose and date of travel. (See Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status)    Passengers coming from Red Category countries without proof of two COVID-19 vaccinations must undergo a PCR test within 72 hours prior to departure and provide proof of a negative result. You must then undergo another PCR test upon arrival at Larnaca or Paphos airports. Test results should be available within three hours through the online platform. The cost of both tests is borne by the passenger.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210816105506/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/cyprus/entry-requirements

Workplaces are open, with social distancing and other hygiene measures in place, exemptions for masks e.g. medical reasons  https://web.archive.org/web/20210829095928/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/employment/hygienic-measures-workplace

Events can continue as usual, with restrictions on gatherings, hygiene measures and testing requirements in place  'Cultural events' require at least an FFP2/KN95 mask  https://web.archive.org/web/20210829103915/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/culture/social-events

Limit of 2000 people outdoors and 1000 indoors with testing and vaccination requirements of attendees  https://web.archive.org/web/20210829103915/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/culture/social-events

Public transport is open as usual, with FFP2/KN95 mask requirements (with medical and preschool age restrictions)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210829110959/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/face-masks-and-respirators/public-transport-taxi

Stratified by green-orange-red-dark red  Dark red is most restictive with PCR test between 5-14 days after arrival and quarantine until results  https://web.archive.org/web/20210829114326/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/foreigners/possibilities-and-obligations-foreigners-when-entering-cz

No change: To support employment, the state will provide 100 billion CZK in direct support and 900 billion CZK indirectly in the form of guarantees. There are also provisions for the self-employed  https://web.archive.org/web/20210817195715/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/

No change to existing guidance: A moratorium proposal on the repayment of loans and mortgages signed before 26 March 2020, which will be binding on all banks and non-banking companies, has been adopted. Both natural persons and corporate debtors will be able to suspend their repayments for three or six months, as they choose. The debtor must notify this intention to the creditor by declaration that he/she/it is taking this action because of the negative economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. However, he/she/it will not have to provide proof of this.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210817195715/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/
There is a coordinated public information campaign  https://web.archive.org/web/20210829114326/https://covid.gov.cz/en/

As of June 1st: testing is voluntary, with once-weekly antigen testing and 2 monthly PCR tests being reimbursed from national insurance  On August 19, the Czech government has decided that starting from September 1, only one antigene testing per 7Â days and two PCR testings per month will continue to be reimbursed; the reimbursement will apply solely to selected population groups:  children up to 17,99 years of age  persons who are unable to get vaccinated due to aÂ contraindication  persons who are either semi-vaccinated or fully vaccinated but the 14-day timespan since they have got their last dose administered has not yet elapsed  https://web.archive.org/web/20210815134432/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/antigen-testing-sars-cov-2/information-comprehensive-testing-using-antigen-tests

Both self-tracing and government contact tracing is done for all confirmed cases identified by positive PCR. For asymptomatic cases: all 'epidemiologically significant' contacts from 5 days to 1 week before the test result. For symptomatic cases: all 'epidemiologically significant' contacts for 2 days prior to the positive result.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210829172903/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/infection-and-general-measures/how-does-tracing-work

"InÂ places with aÂ high concentration of people and in all indoor areas where it is not possible to keep a distance of at least 1.5m from others, it is necessary to have aÂ respirator or other protective equipment without an exhalation valve with aÂ filtration efficiency of at least 94% (class FFP2 / KN 95)." Exemptions: at home or other accommodation, pre-school children, within the same household, serious mental illness intellectual impairment or health issue certified by a doctor  Masks are not compulsory outdoors except on public transport and at events (see events guidance)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210829173517/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/face-masks-and-respirators/indoors
Vaccination is voluntary and free for everyone over the age of 12  https://web.archive.org/web/20210829183549/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/register-vaccination/vaccination-timeline

There are some testing and hygiene measures required, but visits are allowed within these constraint  https://web.archive.org/web/20210702092535/https://covid.gov.cz/en/measures/hospitals-and-social-services/restrictions-visits-social-care-facilities

Starting 1 Aug, risk areas will be classified in two categories: high risk areas and virus variant areas. The category of âsimpleâ risk areas does not apply. Now all those entering - regardless of whether they have been in a high-risk area or virus variant area or not - are obliged to provide evidence of the absence of an infection with the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus (vaccination, test -, proof of recovery). Non-vaccinated or those untested are required to undergo quarantine regulations if they are entering Germany from a risk area. (The Coronavirus Entry Ordinance of 30 July, 2021)     Sources:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210823175326/https://www.bundesgesundheitsministerium.de/service/gesetze-und-verordnungen/guv-19-lp/coronaeinreisev.html

The Danish travel restrictions classify all countries and regions into four colour categories: green, yellow, orange and red. These categories determine which rules apply to you. Countries in the red zone have the strictest guidelines requiring: a test required prior to boarding aircraft, test and isolation required after entry, with foreigners requiring a worthy purpose for entry to Denmark, and to take test prior to entry to Denmark (EU Digital COVID Certificate)    https://archive.vn/R8X5Q

In Denmark, a face mask or shield is required at the airport and while standing up when using public transportation. You are advised to wear a face mask or shield at test centres or when you visit the hospital. However, some groups are exempt from the required use of face mask or shield. These include, for instance, children up to the age of 12, people with a decreased level of consciousness, or people with physical or mental impairments that make it impossible for them to remove the face mask or shield themselves. Face masks may be removed if the wearer experience a severe discomfort, such as difficulty breathing      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210811122501/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

* Travellers arriving by air, sea or land, with the exception of children under 12 years of age, must certify one of the following requirements:    1. Certificate of recovery from COVID-19 issued by the competent authorities or medical service.   2. Diagnostic certificate: a negative PCR or PCR-like test.    * Quarantine remains for nationals from Colombia, Argentina, Bolivia and Brasil.    Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20210823203453/https://travelbans.org/europe/spain/ *** https://web.archive.org/web/20210823203559/https://www.infobae.com/america/tendencias-america/2021/08/22/espana-estudia-levantar-las-cuarentenas-para-viajeros-de-argentina-y-otros-paises-latinoamericanos/

- A: Key workers, nationally covered.  - B: clinically vulnerable people are eligible for vaccination nationally.  - C: People over 80 are fully covered at the national level with two doses. Almost full coverage in 70-79 age group with two doses (100%).  - Extended coverage in 60-69 (94.7%), 50-59 (93.2%), 40-49 (82.2%) ages groups.   - Extended coverage in 30-39 (62.9%).  - Medium coverage in 20-29 age group (45.3%)  - Low coverage in 12-17 age group (14.8%).    * Vaccines administered: Pfizer / BioNtech, Moderna, AstraZeneca / Oxford, Jansenn.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210823201930/https://www.rtve.es/noticias/20210823/campana-vacunacion-espana/2062499.shtml

Schools are open as usual with recommended distancing  Doing distance learning due to the parent's wish can happen only upon agreement with the school, provided that the school can manage it.  Educational institutions are very strongly recommended to organise their learning and other activities in ways that reduce contacts between people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210821134711/https://www.kriis.ee/en/education-and-distance-learning
Restrictions on contact training to prevent the spread of the virus should generally be avoided  https://archive.is/kJrhF

Workplaces are open as usual, with some guidance on managing distance working if the employees wish or the employers think it necessary.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210821135219/https://www.kriis.ee/en/work-during-emergency-situation
Distance work can be done only upon an agreement between the parties.  https://archive.is/fEB1P
Events are allowed to continue with some guidance on proof of test result  https://web.archive.org/web/20210821140139/https://www.kriis.ee/en/culture-and-entertainment

Events and activities where the negative test result, recovery from COVID-19, or completion of the course of COVID-19 vaccination of participants is checked, are allowed to have up to 6000 participants indoors and up to 12000 outdoors.  https://archive.is/Vm4tz    It is allowed to carry out public worship services and religious services in a way that up to 50 people may participate in them in places of worship (100 outdoors) or a 50% maximum occupancy requirement has to be observed.  https://archive.is/WQWmf

Starting from August 9, up to 50 people are allowed at indoor and up to 100 people at outdoor events where there is no check. Indoors, the limitation applies to the whole building or territory. At events and activities where the negative test result, recovery from COVID-19 or completed course of COVID-19 vaccination is checked, the current order will remain and up to 6000 people can participate indoors and up to 12000 people outdoors.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210821140139/https://www.kriis.ee/en/culture-and-entertainment

Indoor events and activities with more participants can only be organised if the infection safety and monitoring thereof is ensured. In such cases, there may be up to 6,000 attendees indoors and up to 12,000 outdoors.  https://archive.is/aQKnf
Public transport remains open and there are no internal restrictions on travel  https://web.archive.org/web/20210821140409/https://www.kriis.ee/en/public-transport-within-estonia

There are no stay at home requirements active in Estonia. Social distancing of a 'reasonable distance' is recommended in indoor spaces  https://web.archive.org/web/20210821141219/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/restrictions-in-everyday-life
There are no restrictions on internal movement active in Estonia.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210821140409/https://www.kriis.ee/en/public-transport-within-estonia

Arrivals from non-green-list (according to the EU) must have a negative PCR within 72 hours or a rapid antigen test within 48 hours of entry, if they are not fully vaccinated.  Arrivals from 'at risk' countries must self-isolate for 10 days, which can be shortened with some testing requirements  https://web.archive.org/web/20210821141747/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crossing-estonian-border

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, you may be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory.    Archived: https://archive.ph/gnw5n  https://archive.ph/ALXcH

No change to implementation of current policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20210729142134/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    On 28 July, new policy for middle and high schools was announced by the Minister for National Education, to be implemented from the start of the new school year on 2 September. Use of the Health Pass will not be required in schools. A four-tier system of restrictions will be in place with controls depending on the incidence of COVID-19. In summary:     Level 1 (Green): In person learning at all levels,   Level 2 (Yellow): In person learning at all levels,  Level 3 (Orange): In person learning at primary and middle schools, hybrid learning (alternating distance and in-person learning) in high schools  Level 4 (Red): In person learning in primary schools, hybrid learning for 50% of 3rd year, all 4th year and high school students.    Increasing levels of sanitary requirements, mask-wearing, restrictions on sports, and protocols for contact tracing will be applied at each level. The decision to trigger movement between levels can be taken at either national or department level.     Between 6000 and 7000 vaccination centers will be deployed in or next to schools alongside a campaign to encourage vaccination for children aged 12 and over.     For full details, see https://web.archive.org/web/20210729142325/https://www.gouvernement.fr/sites/default/files/cfiles/cadre-sanitaire-pour-le-fonctionnement-des-coles-et-tablissements-scolaires-ann-e-scolaire-2021-2022-91517.pdf     The Minister also noted that there are currently no plans to make vaccination mandatory for teachers, with approximately 80% of the profession already vaccinated â but that "This figure must go as far as possible towards 100% so that we do not have to go towards compulsory vaccination, this is the last resort. If the percentage of teachers vaccinated is too low, we will have to move towards that" - https://web.archive.org/web/20210729145019/https://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2021/07/28/dans-les-colleges-et-lycees-les-eleves-non-vaccines-seront-evinces-s-il-y-a-un-cas-de-covid-19-dans-une-classe_6089766_3224.html

All business sectors admitting the public (e.g., cafes, restaurants, shops, cinemas) are now open in almost all of France, with targeted restrictions that were enforced in the department of Landes closing nightclubs, indoor standing concerts and outdoor festivals extended until at least 4 August - https://web.archive.org/web/20210725210808/http://www.landes.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/communique_de_presse_-_point_de_situation_sanitaire_dans_les_landes-3.pdf and https://web.archive.org/web/20210725210109/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    In Guadeloupe, a curfew is in place between 21:00 and 5:00 from 30 July - https://web.archive.org/web/20210729162842/https://www.guadeloupe.gouv.fr/Politiques-publiques/Risques-naturels-technologiques-et-sanitaires/Securite-sanitaire/Informations-coronavirus/Mesures-regionales-pour-lutter-contre-la-degradation-epidemique-aigue-de-la-4eme-vague    In Martinique, a lockdown is in place from 19:00 to 5:00. From 5:00 to 19:00, only travel within a radius of 10km is allowed from a person's home, with exceptions for travel to work. Teleworking is recommended, whenever possible. Discotheques are closed. Restuarants are only allowed to serve customers at outdoor tables, or provide take-away services. Restuarants and bars located in enclosed shopping cetners over 5000m2 are not allowed to open, unless only accessible from a public road. https://web.archive.org/web/20210729174015/https://www.martinique.gouv.fr/Politiques-publiques/Environnement-sante-publique/Sante/Informations-COVID-19/La-Martinique-face-au-COVID-19-mesures-attestations-recommandations     Similar restrictions will be introduced in La Reunion from 31 July - https://web.archive.org/web/20210729184634/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Continued from late July, lockdown restrictions remain in force including curfews and restrictions on internal travel in Guadeloupe, Martinique, La Reunion, Saint-Martin and Saint-Barthelemy - https://web.archive.org/web/20210812142431/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    As of 9 August, 2021, the "health pass" is mandatory for access to certain places, establishments or events, indoors or outdoors, now applies regardless of the number of people present, in such as cinemas, museums, cafÃ©s, restaurants, hospitals, retirement homes, medical and social establishments (except in case of emergency). Long distance travel by interregional public transport is also concerned. https://web.archive.org/web/20210812142431/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

In all departments of metropolitan France except Landes (see below), limitations on the number of people who can gather in public have been revoked as of 30 June. https://web.archive.org/web/20210716211324/https://www.gouvernement.fr/sites/default/files/contenu/piece-jointe/2021/05/dp-strategie-reouverture-annexe-v3.pdf    In the department of Landes, the prohibition on gatherings, meetings or activities on the public highway or in the places open to the public with more than twenty people at the same time will be maintained until at least 4 August due to high prevalence of the Delta variant virus - https://web.archive.org/web/20210725210808/http://www.landes.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/communique_de_presse_-_point_de_situation_sanitaire_dans_les_landes-3.pdf    In the overseas territories of Guadaloupe and Martinique, a curfew will be enforced between 7pm and 5am from 30 July for at least 3 weeks. Any gathering of more than 10 people on the public highway is prohibited with the exception of official ceremonies, protest events, sports competitions of less than 50 competitors and events without catering authorized by the mayors in their municipalities. Any participant in a concert, show, screening, meeting or sporting event must be seated and wear a protective mask for the duration of the event. Organizers will not be able to receive more than 75% of the capacity of the establishment. Use of the Health Pass is mandatory for all places where 50 or more people may gather (theaters, amusement parks, concert halls, festivals, sports halls, cinemas) https://web.archive.org/web/20210729174015/https://www.martinique.gouv.fr/Politiques-publiques/Environnement-sante-publique/Sante/Informations-COVID-19/La-Martinique-face-au-COVID-19-mesures-attestations-recommandations and https://web.archive.org/web/20210729162842/https://www.guadeloupe.gouv.fr/Politiques-publiques/Risques-naturels-technologiques-et-sanitaires/Securite-sanitaire/Informations-coronavirus/Mesures-regionales-pour-lutter-contre-la-degradation-epidemique-aigue-de-la-4eme-vague    Similar restrictions will be introduced in La Reunion from 31 July - https://web.archive.org/web/20210729184634/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

No new policy - continued from 9 June, with a system of green/orange/red list countries and different rules for travelers arriving from these lists, and exceptions for certain classes of traveler. Full details at https://web.archive.org/web/20210612160728/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19    In summary:     "Green List" - travellers from a country in the European area or from Australia, South Korea, Israel, Japan, Lebanon, New Zealand, and Singapore, are not subject to "compelling reasons" requirements for visiting France. Must provide evidence of a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before departure, OR proof of complete vaccination with an EMA-approved vaccine.     "Orange List" - from all countries not specified in other lists, must:     - all must present negative results of a PCR test taken 72 hours before departure or an antigen test taken 48 hours before departure  - vaccinate travelers not subject to "compelling reasons" test for entry  - unvaccinated travelers are subject to "compelling reasons", and must self-isolate for 7 days after arrival    "Red List" - travelers from a country listed in the order of the Ministry of Health identifying the areas of active circulation of the epidemic or the spread of variants (currently Argentina, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, India, Nepal, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Suriname, Turkey, Uruguay) must:     - have a "compelling reason" to visit France  - negative results of PCR test taken up to 48 hours before departure  - mandatory antigen test on arrival  - mandatory 10 day quarantine on arrival, unless fully vaccinated in which case 7-day self isolation    The "Compelling Reasons" allows the following to enter France: French nationals, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their principal residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.

If you are not vaccinated and you arrive from a âredâ country  âRed listâÂ countries :Â Countries where active viral circulation has been reported, including relevant variants. These include the following countries: Afghanistan, Argentina, Bangladesh, Brazil, Costa-Rica, Cuba, Democratic Republic of Congo, Indonesia, Maldives, Mozambique, Namibia, Nepal, Oman, Pakistan, Russia, Seychelles, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Suriname and Tunisia.  You can only travel to France if you haveÂ pressing grounds for travel. The list of pressing grounds is set out in the certificate of international travel drawn up by theÂ Ministry of the Interior.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210821184120/https://se.ambafrance.org/COVID-19-Can-I-enter-France

âIf you are vaccinated: you can travel to France with no restrictions linked to health conditions.  The measures applicable to vaccinated adults also apply to any minors accompanying them, whether they are vaccinated or not. You can therefore travel with your underage children, whether they are vaccinated or not, and they will not need to self-isolate. Unvaccinated children aged 12 and over will need to present a negative test result as described below.â   âIf you are not vaccinated and you arrive from a âredâ country  âRed listâ countries : Countries where active viral circulation has been reported, including relevant variants. These include the following countries: Afghanistan, Argentina, Bangladesh, Brazil, Costa-Rica, Cuba, Democratic Republic of Congo, Indonesia, Maldives, Mozambique, Namibia, Nepal, Oman, Pakistan, Russia, Seychelles, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Suriname and Tunisia.  You can only travel to France if you haveÂ pressing grounds for travel. The list of pressing grounds is set out in the certificate of international travel drawn up by theÂ Ministry of the Interior."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210828073257/https://se.ambafrance.org/COVID-19-Can-I-enter-France

Vaccination available to everyone aged over 18  and to adolescent girls between the age of 12 and 17, and to boys between 12 and 18 with parental permission.     From 15 September, vaccination will be mandatory for the following categories of people:   - All staff (including administrative) of health institutions, medico-social institutions (EHPAD, USLD, independent residences, disability structures with or without accommodation and including non-medicalized), social institutions attached to a health institution (LHSS, LAM, CSAPA, CAARUD, CLAT, CEGGID);  - Home help working with people receiving APA or PCH, in the context of home services or as employees of individual employers;  - The staff of medical transport companies (including contracted taxis);  - All professions in Book IV of the CSP, contracted or not, and professions for the use of titles, as well as their employees (e.g. medical secretaries, dental assistants);  - All health students;  - SDIS-Firefighters (professionals and volunteers);  - Occupational health service personnel.    Persons with a contraindication to vaccination will be exempt from the vaccination obligation. Unvaccinated personnel will have until 15 September 2021 to do so, or until 15 October 2021 if they have already received a first dose of vaccine, and present a negative test. A certificate of vaccination status will then be issued to them. Checks will be carried out from 15 September.    Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield, and Janssen vaccines are being administered.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210808165050/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Changes to UK International arrivals lists on 5 Aug:    The UK government has today (5 August 2021) announced that arrivals from France to England will no longer need to quarantine if they are fully vaccinated.    The step aligns France with the rest of the amber list now that the proportion of beta variant cases has fallen, where those who are fully vaccinated with a vaccine authorised and administered in the UK, US or Europe do not need to quarantine when arriving in England.    This move also simplifies the system to 3 categories, as well as the green watchlist to give travellers notice where green status is at risk.    arrivals from France will no longer need to quarantine if they are fully vaccinated  Austria, Germany, Slovenia, Slovakia, Latvia, Romania and Norway to be added to the governmentâs green list for travel  India, Bahrain, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) will also be moved from the red to the amber list  Georgia, Mexico, La Reunion and Mayotte added to the red list to safeguard domestic vaccine rollout    https://web.archive.org/web/20210806111415/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/international-travel-country-listings-update

you must use a facemask in all indoor public and communal spaces, including work-places and on public transport;    restricted numbers are in place for churches and religious services;  Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823090643/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

Following the approval of several Greek State aid schemes to support companies facing economic difficulties due to the coronavirus outbreak, Greece notified to the Commission a scheme to further support companies under the Temporary Framework.    Under the scheme, Greece plans to provide economic assistance to certain businesses in order to bridge liquidity shortages related to the coronavirus outbreak and thereby to preserve continuity of economic activity during and after the outbreak  (iv) Safeguards for banks that channel State aid to the real economy that such aid is considered as direct aid to the banks' customers, not to the banks themselves, and gives guidance on how to ensure minimal distortion of competition between banks.  (x) Targeted support in the form of wage subsidies for employees for those companies in sectors or regions that have suffered most from the coronavirus outbreak, and would otherwise have had to lay off personnel.    https://web.archive.org/https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_21_4101

You can enter Hungary by road, rail and waterway from all the countries neighbouring Hungary (Croatia, Austria, Romania, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia and Ukraine) without any epidemiological restrictions, regardless of your nationality and coronavirus immunity.    Foreign (including UK) nationals may also enter Hungary without any epidemiological restrictions if they hold a negative PCR test conducted in the previous 72 hours in one of the following places: all EU member states and candidate countries; all OECD member states; all NATO member states, member states of the Turkic Council and Bahrain, China, Georgia, India, Indonesia, Russia; Singapore, Ukraine, and the UAE.    If you do not possess a Hungary issued Immunity certificate, a negative PCR test or meet one of the exemptions, you will be required to quarantine upon arrival.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210831090347/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/hungary/entry-requirements

August 5th 2021, for outdoor events/venues a maximum of 200 attendees can attend the majority of venues. A limit of 500 people is in place for venues with capacity greater than 5,000 with appropriate protective measures in place - including social distancing requirements.    Summer camps should adhere to public health measures on organised indoor and outdoor activities as appropriate, applying at the time. Currently outdoor camps can go ahead, but indoor camps are not permitted.    From Thursday 5 August, Baptism services may proceed. However, they must follow all protective measures and social gatherings afterwards should be avoided.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210810100837/https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/7894b-post-cabinet-statement-resilience-and-recovery-the-path-ahead/

Ireland is now a part of the EU Digital COVID Certificate for travel originating within the EU/EEA. The Digital COVID Certificate will make it easier to travel to and from these countries and will be accepted as proof of vaccination, recovery or negative test.    Passengers arriving into Ireland from inside EU + Iceland, Lichtenstein, Norway, Switzerland:  If you have valid proof of vaccination, no travel-related testing or quarantine will be necessary.    If you have valid proof that you have recovered from COVID in the past 180 days, no travel-related testing or quarantine will be necessary.    If you do not have valid proof of vaccination or recovery, you will need to present evidence of a negative RT-PCR result from a test taken within 72 hours prior to arrival into the country      If your journey originates in a country to which an emergency brake has not been applied  If you have valid proof of vaccination, no travel-related testing or quarantine will be necessary.    If you have valid proof of recovery from COVID in the past 180 days, no travel-related testing or quarantine will be necessary.    If you do not have valid proof of vaccination or recovery, you will need to:    present evidence of a negative result from a RT-PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to arrival into the country  self-quarantine for 14 days  if you receive a negative result from a RT-PCR test taken from day 5 onwards after arrival into Ireland, you will be able to leave quarantine  If your journey originates in a country to which an emergency brake has been applied  If you have valid proof of vaccination, you will need to:    present evidence of a negative result from a RT-PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival  undergo self-quarantine  if you receive a negative result from a RT-PCR test taken from day 5 onwards after arrival into Ireland, you will be able to leave quarantine  If you have valid proof that you have recovered from COVID-19 in the past 180 days, you will need to:    present evidence of a negative result from a RT-PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival  undergo self-quarantine  if you receive a negative result from a RT-PCR test taken from day 5 onwards after arrival into Ireland, you will be able to leave quarantine  If you do not have valid proof of vaccination or recovery, you will need to:    present evidence of a negative RT-PCR test result taken in previous 72 hours before arrival  undergo mandatory hotel quarantine  if you receive a negative result from a RT-PCR test taken from day 10 onwards after arrival into Ireland, you will be able to leave quarantine    https://web.archive.org/web/20210731073501/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/77952-government-advice-on-international-travel/

From 11 August 2021, travellers into Ireland with an EU Digital COVID Certificate must be fully vaccinated with an EMA-approved vaccine to be considered exempt from:    - mandatory hotel quarantine  - self-quarantine  - having a negative RT-PCR test result taken within 72 hours prior to arrival in the country or a positive RT-PCR test result taken not less than 11 days and not more than 180 days before arrival in the State    These rules may be different if you are travelling from a designated state.    On your arrival into the State, you must quarantine in a designated hotel if you:    - have been in, or transited through, a designated State within 14 days prior to your arrival; even if you have a negative RT-PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to your arrival or  - have been in any other country and arrive without valid evidence of a negative RT-PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to your arrival or  - do not have valid evidence that you first tested positive for COVID-19 with a RT-PCR test taken no more than 180 days and less than 11 days prior to your arrival or  - are not an exempt traveller    https://web.archive.org/web/20210816054940/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/a6975-mandatory-hotel-quarantine/

From 11 August 2021, travellers into Ireland with an EU Digital COVID Certificate must be fully vaccinated with an EMA-approved vaccine to be considered exempt from:    - mandatory hotel quarantine  - self-quarantine  - having a negative RT-PCR test result taken within 72 hours prior to arrival in the country or a positive RT-PCR test result taken not less than 11 days and not more than 180 days before arrival in the State    These rules may be different if you are travelling from a designated state.    On your arrival into the State, you must quarantine in a designated hotel if you:    - have been in, or transited through, a designated State within 14 days prior to your arrival; even if you have a negative RT-PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to your arrival or  - have been in any other country and arrive without valid evidence of a negative RT-PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to your arrival or  - do not have valid evidence that you first tested positive for COVID-19 with a RT-PCR test taken no more than 180 days and less than 11 days prior to your arrival or  - are not an exempt traveller    https://web.archive.org/web/20210816054940/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/a6975-mandatory-hotel-quarantine/

As of 27 July, all vaccinated persons and those that can present a certificate of a prior COVID-19 infection must present a negative PCR or antigen (rapid) test that is no more than 72 hours old before departure to Iceland. Unvaccinated individuals will continue to be required to present negative PCR test results no more than 72 hours old and undergo double PCR screening with a five-day quarantine in between.    Travellers from outside the EEA/EFTA area who are not relatives of an EEA/EFTA citizen and not from exempted countries may not enter Iceland unless they provide a valid reason.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210727085508/https://island.is/en/p/entry  https://web.archive.org/web/20210727084845/https://www.government.is/news/article/2021/07/19/COVID-19-test-certificate-required-before-departure-for-vaccinated-travellers/

As of August 16, vaccinated passengers with ties to Iceland must undergo testing within 48 hours of arrival in Iceland.  These passengers will not be required to enter into quarantine until after the results of the testing are available.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210817002850/https://www.government.is/news/article/2021/08/09/Vaccinated-passengers-with-ties-to-Iceland-to-undergo-testing/

All travellers who enter Iceland, and are considered to have close ties within the Icelandic community, will need to undergo an additional covid-19 test upon arrival in Iceland. They are not required to quarantine, but are asked to limit their interactions in the first few days after arrival.    Vaccinated passengers (and those with a prior infection) born in 2004 or earlier, must present a negative PCR or antigen test (not older than 72 hours) prior to boarding a vessel to Iceland. They are not required to be tested at the border or to quarantine upon arrival.    Travellers from outside the EEA/EFTA area who are not relatives of an EEA/EFTA citizen and not from exempted countries may not enter Iceland unless the provide a valid reason.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210831083554/https://island.is/en/p/entry

Masks must be worn indoors wherever the one-metre social distancing rule cannot be observed between individuals who are not closely linked, with the exception of certain events where guests are seated in booked seats. Children born 2006 or later are not obliged to wear a mask.  Face masks shall also be used indoors where it is not possible to ensure a one-metre proximity limit, such as in health services, stores, domestic flights and ferries, public transport and other similar activities. Face masks must cover the nose and mouth.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210831083547/https://www.covid.is/categories/effective-restrictions-on-gatherings

The government approved a new decree (DL 6 August 2021 n. 111) containing "Urgent measure for the secure exercise of school, university, social activities and transportation". The decree states for the school year 2021/22 lessons will be in presence from kindergarten to high school, and unless not possible for university. However, social distancing and containment measures remain: pupils (ages 6+) and teachers are required to wear masks, a distance of at least 1 metre is recommended, and entrance to school facilities and buildings is prohibited for those exhibiting respiratory or flu-like symptoms or with a temperature of 37.5 degrees and above. All school personnel has to be in possession of a COVID green pass (EU digital COVID certificate). The pass can be obtained by completing the COVID-19 vaccination cycle, being in possession of a negative molecular or antigen test taken within 48 hours, being in possession of a certificate of recovery from COVID-19 dated within six months. In case of a positive COVID-19 test in a classroom, individual regions/school district officials can decide to forgo normal containment measures in case the entire class is vaccinated. In person schooling can be stopped by region presidents if their region is in a red/orange zone and/or there is an extremely high risk of contagion. Source: http://archive.today/ayxMd | http://archive.today/GyyAg

Teleworking  is no longer compulsory, but is strongly recommended. Businesses including restaurants, bars, theaters, and casinos are allowed to open with restrictions on capacity and health measures in place. Shops may open with a limit of one person per 4 mÂ².     Restaurants and bars in Monaco must limit tables to ten people or fewer, observe social distancing rules, and require booking in advance. From July 24, some customers are also required to present a valid health pass. Theaters, casinos, and public halls may operate at 70% capacity with a maximum of 1,000 people.
